Award.AwardTitle: The Regularity of Cauchy-Riemann Mappings and Solutions of Systems of Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this research project is to study the solutions of systems of partial differential equations that arise in several complex variables. Important mathematical applications of this research include establishing the regularity of solutions and the convergence of solutions for which only Taylor series coefficients are known. Important applications to physical systems include equations that arise in statistical mechanics and meteorology. For example, the planar dimer model is a statistical mechanical model of certain two-dimensional surfaces in space that is a higher dimensional generalization of the simple random walk on integers. The limit shape of such surfaces is modeled by a partial differential equation closely related to the complex Burgers' equation studied in this project. The same equation is also relevant in the study of the quasi-geostrophic equations that model the behavior of certain atmospheric phenomena.

The main part of the project involves the problem of understanding geometric conditions that imply that a sufficiently smooth CR mapping between two Cauchy-Riemann (CR) manifolds is smooth when the manifolds are smooth, and real analytic when the manifolds are real analytic. Closely related problems that will be investigated include the local and microlocal regularity of CR functions on abstract CR manifolds. The tools that may be used include a new family of Fourier-Bros-Iagolnitzer transforms, analytic discs, and the methods developed in the theory of holomorphic extendability of CR functions on hypersurfaces.

Institution.Name: Temple University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of the project consist of new results on the validity of unique continuation for two types of problems, namely, unique continuation for CR mappings and boundary unique continuation for solutions of certain second order partial differential equations. Unique continuation was explored for CR mappings between embedded CR manifolds. A related unique continuation problem conjectured by Baouendi and Rothschild was investigated for solutions of second order elliptic partial differential equations with real analytic coefficients.

The general problem on unique continuation for CR mappings is as follows: suppose a CR mapping between two embedded CR manifolds vanishes to infinite order at a point. When can we conclude that the mapping vanishes identically in a neighborhood of the point in question? Very few sufficient conditions are known even when both manifolds are real analytic hypersurfaces and the mapping is smooth and is the boundary value of a holomorphic function from a side. Sufficient geometric conditions on the CR manifolds were established for the validity of unique continuation. Progress was also made on the conjecture of Baouendi and Rothschild by establishing the boundary uniqueness property for the solutions of the Helmholtz equation and for a class of second order elliptic partial differential equations in the plane.

The outcomes led to four papers three of which have been published and the fourth one is under review by a journal.

The Intellectual Merits of the outcomes comprise the fact that the results have important applications to function theory of several complex variables, CR Geometry, and the theory of linear and nonlinear partial differential equations. The second order partial differential equations studied in this project arise in many problems in analysis, geometry, applied mathematics, statistics, physics, and engineering. These equations are relevant to physically significant partial differential equations such as the wave equation, the heat equation, the Klein-Gordon equation, Maxwell's and Schrodinger's equations.

 In terms of Broader Impacts, the PI has been engaged in a number of synergistic activities including arranging for the participation of graduate students and recent Ph.D.'s in several workshops. Research collaborations by young researchers have resulted from such workshops. As the Graduate Program Chair of his department, he worked hard to help improve the recruitment and retention of graduate students from under-represented groups. 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2019
Modified by: Shiferaw Berhanu
